course.title: Oxygen
course.description: Comprehensive course on Oxygen administration and safety in diving operations.

sections.title: Have you Completed your PRE-TEST
sections.content:
If not, close this manual and Select the Pre-Test

A pre-test helps measure true learning.  You are not expected to know the answers to all of the questions.

A pre-test helps you:

Identify your knowledge gaps (topics you don't know or have forgotten!).

Identify where you need to focus (pay attention to your weaker areas).

The pre-test is done once. It is not a a pass/fail test. Enjoy!

2. Introduction

Legislative requirements require that oxygen be available at the dive site.

Warning:No portable oxygen systems are to be taken into the chamber.
sections.title: Introduction

subsections.title: When to Provide Oxygen
subsections.content:
Oxygen provides life support by restoring tissue oxygen levels in a range of conditions,

Serious illness

Serious injury

Heart Attack and Stroke

Breathing difficulty (Drowning, suffocation, running out of air)

Carbon monoxide poisoning or other gas contamination

Decompression Illness (DCI)

subsections.title: Roles and Responsibilities of an Operational Dive Team
subsections.content:
It is generally accepted that the diving team has been systematically and thoroughly informed and trained with regards to the procedures to be followed in the case of an emergency. 
It also advises that when diving operations are undertaken, sufficient stored quantities of medical oxygen is available at the dive site so that an emergency may be dealt with effectively.

The Diving Supervisor

The Diving Supervisor is ultimately responsible for the safety of the divers during the course of the Diving Operation. The supervisor should appoint a competent oxygen provider in the event of an emergency.

subsections.title: The Oxygen Provider
subsections.content: The Oxygen Provider will be responsible for the Oxygen Administration System.

subsections.title: Duties of the Oxygen Provider
subsections.content:
To ensure oxygen is on site, clearly labeled and easily accessible.

To ensure daily checks and function tested according to a check list.

To be familiar with the oxygen administration system.

To check and record the pressure in the oxygen system prior to commencing diving operations. (Ensure oxygen is full)

To ensure the oxygen cylinder is re-filled and all disposable items are replaced after any incident.

subsections.title: Responsibilities of the Oxygen Provider in an Emergency
subsections.content:
Safe Set Up– To ensure safe connection of oxygen administration systems.

Secure Positioning– To ensure the cylinder is prevented from falling or rolling.

Right Mask- To select the right mask for the right patient and connect appropriately.

Right Flow- To ensure the right flow rate is used.

Good Fit- To ensure a good mask seal or fit.

Good Airway -To ensure an open airway and effective breathing.

Positioning-To ensure the correct positioning of the injured person.

Documentation and Good House Keeping –To maintain the oxygen check lists, documentation in the event of an incident.

Good House Keeping -To maintain, cleaning, restocking, refilling cylinder and correct storage.

They should NOT be used unless they are oxygen clean and correctly certified.

The Pressure regulator should be well protected at all times.
sections.title: Types of Oxygen Pressure Regulators

subsections.title: Pin Index
subsections.content:
The pin index is a unique configuration of holes and pins which match precisely to eliminate connection of the wrong cylinder to equipment. All pin index systems have anoxygen washer(Bodok seal).

Oxygen washers(bodok seals) are an essential part of the system, without them the oxygen will leak out.  Always ensure the correct washer is in place and keep one spare.

The washer comes in a sealed packet so they can not get contaminated with oil and grease!

sections.title: Oxygen Mask Summary
sections.content: 3.1. Assembling Portable Oxygen

sections.title: Assembly of Portable Oxygen Systems
sections.content:
Make sure you know this well in preparation for your work place assessment!

Care should be taken in the handling and use of medical oxygen cylinders.

Never attempt to fit a regulator to an incompatible cylinder.  Ensure that you have the correct regulator for the type of cylinder you are intending to use.

Never use medical oxygen from a cylinder without reducing the pressure through a suitable regulator intended for that gas.

Never permit compressed medical oxygen to suddenly enter the Pressure Regulator.  Open valves slowly.

Avoid carrying the portable oxygen system by the valve.  If carrying the systems carry with two hands.

All gauges must read ZERO prior to disconnecting the components.  Never work on a pressurised system.

Always close the cylinder valve and disconnect the regulator when not in use.

Never immerse the regulator in any fluid.

No adhesive tape should be put around the cylinder pillar valve, or regulator assembly as it can increase fire hazard risk.

4. Oxygen Masks

Manually Triggered Ventilator

The device can be used as:

Demand inhalator valve for the Injured Person (IP) is breathing or

Manually Triggered Ventilator (MTV) for the non breathing injured diver. The button can be depressed over one (1) second to deliver a breath.

Warning:Oxygen supports combustion and smoking should be prohibited when oxygen is in use.

Warning:No portable oxygen can be taken into the chamber.

4.1. Breathing Casualty

subsections.title: Alive Diver
subsections.content:
Oxygen can be provided to any Injured Person (IP), who is breathing effectively, using the following oxygen masks:

Demand Inhalator Valve and Mask- for use by the Injured Person (IP) with life signs - Conscious, Alert and Orientated.

Non Rebreather Mask- for use by the Injured Person (IP) who is

conscious but can not tolerate the Demand Valve or

unconscious Injured Persons with effective breathing. (Life signs)

subsections.title: Dead Diver
subsections.content:
Oxygen can be provided to any Injured Person (IP), who is not breathing effectively, using the following oxygen masks:

Pocket mask (Oronasal) Resuscitator- Unresponsive with no life signs.

Bag Valve Mask (BVM) Resuscitator- Unresponsive with no life signs.

sections.title: Dead Diver
sections.content:
Oxygen can be provided to any Injured Person (IP), who is not breathing effectively, using the following oxygen masks:

Pocket mask (Oronasal) Resuscitator- Unresponsive with no life signs.

Bag Valve Mask (BVM) Resuscitator- Unresponsive with no life signs.

An Injured Person who is conscious, alert and orientated.

To activate the Demand Valve (DV) the Injured Person must hold the mask, create an adequate seal and breathe with enough effort to activate the system.

When using oxygen on demand remember the oxygen cylinder must be open and the flow rate meter must be on Zero (0) LPM.

Advantages:

High concentrations of oxygen.

If sealed correctly to the face the Demand Valve (DV) delivers 100% oxygen - True Fit Mask.

The mask is clear so the airway and breathing can be monitored easily.

The oxygen supply lasts longer.

Disadvantages:

Only ideal for Injured Persons (IP) who is conscious and alert.

The Injured Person (IP) must hold the mask.

Requires a good seal and enough breathing effort to activate the demand valve.

It is not ideal if the Injured Person (IP) loses consciousness.

Constant Flow - Non-Rebreather Mask (NRM)

The non rebreather mask can be used on either:

An Injured Person who is conscious, alert and orientated and who cannot tolerate the Demand Valve (DV) or

An Injured Person who is unconscious with effective breathing (life signs).

When using the Non-Rebreather Mask the oxygen flow meter must be on 15LPM.

Advantages:

High concentrations of oxygen.

Provides up to 90% oxygen from the attached reservoir bag. (Percentage depends on the depth and rate of breathing.)

Light weight.

Easily fitted to the face.

No need to hold the mask.

Well tolerated.

Requires no effort to breathe from.

The mask is clear so the airway and breathing can be monitored easily.

Disadvantages:

Only for use on Injured Persons (IP) who are breathing effectively.

Continuous flow uses up oxygen supply quicker than demand oxygen supply.

The components are:

Clear oral nasal maskwith a metal strip over the nose and an elastic strap to ensure correct fit.

A reservoir bagwith a one-way valve to prevent any rebreathing (hence the name non-rebreather mask)

Two exhalation portswith one-way valves to direct the exhaled breath out of the mask.

Good Practice point:Reservoir bag must always be fully inflated (primed) before administering oxygen to the Injured Person (IP).  Always use a flow of 15L/min.

DO NOT cover the reservoir bag with a blanket.  Continuously ensure an adequate airway and effective breathing.  Do not accidentally step on or disconnect the tubing.

sections.content:
Pocket mask contains a replaceable one-way valve that safeguards you as the First-Aider from viruses and bacteria that cause diseases such as tuberculosis and hepatitis.

The pocket mask can deliver:

50% oxygen at 10 LPM

80% oxygen at 15 LPM

The pocket mask is used on a dead person who is not breathing effectively and only occasionally gasping or not breathing at all. (Unresponsive with no life signs).

Advantages:

Easy to use

Eliminates direct mouth to mouth contact.

The one way valve prevents exhaled air and body fluids from coming into contact with the First-Aider or Oxygen Provider. Body Substance Isolation (BSI)

Use of oxygen inlets provides a high concentration of oxygen.

Disadvantages:

Warning- No effective mask seal = No effective Breathing

If using incorrect position it may close off the airway.

If no effective face to mask seal is made then there will be no effective breath.

The Pocket Mask should never be coupled to advanced breathing equipment or to the Bag Valve Mask.

Remove air filters - if they get wet they prevent effective ventilation.

Competence in using a Pocket Mask

Manage the Injured Persons (IP) airway using the Head tilt-Chin lift or Jaw Thrust and create a tight seal.

Always ensure a good seal. If the seal is inadequate then so are the ventilations!

Give two (2) gentle breaths. Each breath should be given over one (1) second. Look for the rise and fall of the chest.

During compressions the mask can be removed and the head turned to the side to prevent any inhalation of body fluids.

Continue with two (2) breaths to thirty (30) good quality chest compressions.

Good practice Point -Look for adequate chest rise and fall to ensure breathing is EFFECTIVE and VENTILATION is adequate.

subsections.title: Barrier Devices
subsections.content:
All Injured Person (IP) that are not breathing or giving an occasional gasp will need assistance with ventilation.

Oxygen masks are transparent so you can see the face and monitor the airway and breathing. If any signs of body fluid is seen collecting in the mask the head must be immediately turned to the side and the mask must be removed

Any Injured Person (IP) receiving CPR needs to be lying on a firm flat surface.

The barrier device protects the First-Aider from disease transmission whilst giving effective ventilation. Use of barrier devices follows the advice of the world health organisation (WHO) regarding Standard Precautions (SP) and Body Substance Isolation (BSI).

The following barrier devices can be used if there is no effective breathing or the Injured Person (IP) is in Sudden Cardiac Arrest (SCA):

Face Shield

Pocket mask Resuscitator with oxygen

Good Practice Point:It is important to ensure an open airway when using a Pocket Mask or Bag Valve Mask Resuscitator.

subsections.title: The Face Shield
subsections.content: This the most basic of barrier devices.  It cannot be connected to oxygen.

sections.content: This the most basic of barrier devices.  It cannot be connected to oxygen.

If you select a non-rebreather mask on a flow of 15 liters per minute then you will use 15 liters of gas every minute so the consumption is 15lpm.  To figure out how long this will last you take the available gas and divide is by the consumption.

Time = available gas ÷ consumption

Time  = 420l ÷ 15 LPM = 28 minutes of oxygen supply!

Hope you got it!!

Although not ideal, you can breathe the oxygen contents to Zero (0) in an emergency - no need to leave 50 bar in the cylinder!!

6. Oxygen Safety
sections.title: How Much Oxygen

subsections.title: Available Gas
subsections.content:
There is guidance in many countries regarding the amount of oxygen that is required at the dive site, for example in South Africa there is a requirement that:  “when diving operations are undertaken, sufficient stored quantities of medical oxygen is available at the dive site so that an emergency may be dealt with effectively”.

Other references, such as IMCA state

"...quantities of gases needed ... for therapeutic treatments and emergencies will need to be calculated when planning a diving project"

"and the risk assessment should address the method of evacuation of the diver with adequate oxygen and medical supplies during transit to the designated chamber identified for recompression"

Good Practice Point.The guidance in many countries, in support of inshore diving, recommends that there is a sufficient portable supply of oxygen to last until arrival at the designated chamber facility or other appropriate medical facility, usually deemed to be between 1-2 hours.

When ever you look at a cylinder you must find out two (2) things;

The size of the cylinder (found on the neck of a cylinder and indicated as water capacity (WC))

The pressure of the cylinder (found by opening the cylinder and reading the contents or pressure gauge)

Always remember the available gas is found by multiplying the size of the cylinder by the pressure.

Cylinder size x Cylinder Pressure = Available Oxygen

For example:

a 3l cylinder pressurised to 140bar

Available oxygen = Cylinder size x Cylinder Pressure

Available oxygen = 3l x 140bar =420l of available oxygen

Good Practice Point.Always remove the pressure regulator and keep main cylinder valve closed during storage.

Good Practice Point.Always keepall components, dry and free from oils and grease.

Good Practice Point.Always check the storage area is well ventilated

Good Practice Point.Alwaysprotect all components and prevent any rolling or falling of the cylinder. This may damage the valve and/or the regulator.

subsections.title: General Safety
subsections.content:
Always be aware of the dangers of oxygen - if in doubt ask.

Good Practice Point.Always ensure equipment is oxygen clean and in good working order.

Good Practice Point.Prevent cylinders from rolling or falling. It may damage the valve and/or the regulator.

Good Practice Point.Maintain all hoses, valves and connections in good condition.

Check for rust or corrosion - If noted remove from service.

Never use near machinery that produces sparks.

Never smoke where oxygen is being used.

subsections.title: Preparation
subsections.content:
Good Practice Point.  Carry the cylinder with both hands and never by the valve or regulator.

Good Practice Point.  Always ensure your hands or gloves are clean.

Good Practice Point.Always connect cylinder and pressure regulator carefully and open valves slowly.

Always ensure equipment has no leaks.

Good Practice Point.Remember to turn on required flow when using oxygen masks.

When using an AED remember to move oxygen away when a shock is required.

Cylinders containing oxygen should be fitted with an approved regulator by which the rate of flow can be controlled.

It is important that the regulator be free from oil or grease, otherwise a violent explosion may occur.

Portable oxygen can not be take into the chamber.

7. Basic Life Support (Review)

sections.title: Basic Life Support
sections.content:
CPR for Every One - South African example

8. Standards of Care (Review)

Check for obvious life signs or a pulse.

A pulse check may be done however if an injured person is breathing it is assumed they have a pulse.

Gasping often occurs just before someone stops breathing and the heart stops. If the person looks like they are gasping for air (like a goldfish!) either forcefully or weak and there are long pauses between breaths, then immediately commence continuous chest compressions (CPR).

7) Rapid Assessment

Check for obvious injuries

Look for and treat any obvious Injury or Illness.

9. Practical Skill Sheet
sections.title: Standards of Care (review)

subsections.title: Review of the Primary Survey (7 Steps)
subsections.content:
Definition:Everyone has the belief (expectation) that people called to help with an emergency are able to give care with an acceptable (adequate) level of knowledge and skill. This is referred to as the ‘Standards of Care’.  This systematic standard approach helps to maintain and improve the quality of care.

The Standards of Care should be communicated effectively and well understood by everyone involved in the management of an injured person (IP).

Hazards

Help

Hello

Airway

Breathing

Circulation

Rapid Assessment.

subsections.title: 1) Hazards
subsections.content:
Identify and eliminate any work place dangers

Safeguard yourself.

Safeguard the scene (area) - no smoking, stop all activities nearby that may be generating a sparks or flame.

Safeguard the Injured Person.

subsections.title: 2) Hello
subsections.content:
Check for response. Assess if the Injured Person is conscious or unconscious.

Anyone who is conscious is alert, awake and orientated. The can manage their own airway, breathe effectively and speak using full sentences.

Anyone who is unconscious and not making any sound or movement should be assessed to see if they are breathing (alive) or not breathing (dead).
Early recognition helps you to choose the right oxygen delivery device.

subsections.title: 3) Help
subsections.content:
Send for help.

Notify the supervisor and request help from your fellow team mates.

Access the Portable Oxygen

subsections.title: 4) Airway
subsections.content:
Open the airway.

The First Responder must ensure the airway is clear and there are no obstructions.

The conscious Injured Person (IP) will be able to manage their own airway

The unconscious Injured Person (IP) will not be able to manage their own airway effectively. The most common obstruction is the tongue. Open the airway using either:

Head Tilt Chin Lift (No neck injury)

Jaw Thrust with motion restriction (if a neck injury is suspected)

subsections.title: 5) Breathing
subsections.content:
Look, Listen and Feel for effective breathing over 10 seconds.

Look:    	for movement of the chest.

Listen:  	for noisy breathing.

Feel:     	for exhaled air against your cheek and place a hand on the chest to feel for movement.

Good Practice Point -Breathing must be normal and regular. Ideally a minimum of 2 breaths should be taken during the 10 second check.

Oxygen Administration

Conscious and Breathing: Request oxygen and administer using a Demand Valve Mask (flow rate 0) or a Non-Re-Breather Mask (flow rate 15 Lpm).

Unconscious and Breathing:  Request oxygen and administer using a Non-Re-Breather Mask (flow rate of 15 Lpm).  Place the injured person in recovery position.

Ineffective Breathing, gasping or No Breathing at All– Deliver breaths using a pocket mask resuscitator attached to oxygen at a flow rate 15 lpm.

Jaw Thrust with motion restriction (if a neck injury is suspected)

sections.title: 5) Breathing
sections.content:
Look, Listen and Feel for effective breathing over 10 seconds.

Look:    	for movement of the chest.

Listen:  	for noisy breathing.

Feel:     	for exhaled air against your cheek and place a hand on the chest to feel for movement.

Good Practice Point -Breathing must be normal and regular. Ideally a minimum of 2 breaths should be taken during the 10 second check.

Oxygen Administration

Conscious and Breathing: Request oxygen and administer using a Demand Valve Mask (flow rate 0) or a Non-Re-Breather Mask (flow rate 15 Lpm).

Unconscious and Breathing:  Request oxygen and administer using a Non-Re-Breather Mask (flow rate of 15 Lpm).  Place the injured person in recovery position.

Ineffective Breathing, gasping or No Breathing at All– Deliver breaths using a pocket mask resuscitator attached to oxygen at a flow rate 15 lpm.

sections.title: Practical Skill Sheet
sections.content: Ensure you are well prepared for your work place assessment and can carry out all the steps.

sections.title: Administration of Oxygen -Conscious (responsive) and Breathing
sections.content:
Make sure you know this well in preparation for your practical assessment!

Verbalise the steps as you go to show you level of knowledge and competence.

sections.title: When to Provide Oxygen
sections.content:
Oxygen provides life support by restoring tissue oxygen levels in a range of conditions,

Serious illness

Serious injury

Heart Attack and Stroke

Breathing difficulty (Drowning, suffocation, running out of air)

Carbon monoxide poisoning or other gas contamination

Decompression Illness (DCI)

sections.title: Roles and Responsibilities of an Operational Dive Team
sections.content:
It is generally accepted that the diving team has been systematically and thoroughly informed and trained with regards to the procedures to be followed in the case of an emergency. 
It also advises that when diving operations are undertaken, sufficient stored quantities of medical oxygen is available at the dive site so that an emergency may be dealt with effectively.

The Diving Supervisor

The Diving Supervisor is ultimately responsible for the safety of the divers during the course of the Diving Operation. The supervisor should appoint a competent oxygen provider in the event of an emergency.

sections.title: The Oxygen Provider
sections.content: The Oxygen Provider will be responsible for the Oxygen Administration System.

sections.title: Duties of the Oxygen Provider
sections.content:
To ensure oxygen is on site, clearly labeled and easily accessible.

To ensure daily checks and function tested according to a check list.

To be familiar with the oxygen administration system.

To check and record the pressure in the oxygen system prior to commencing diving operations. (Ensure oxygen is full)

To ensure the oxygen cylinder is re-filled and all disposable items are replaced after any incident.

sections.title: Responsibilities of the Oxygen Provider in an Emergency
sections.content:
Safe Set Up– To ensure safe connection of oxygen administration systems.

Secure Positioning– To ensure the cylinder is prevented from falling or rolling.

Right Mask- To select the right mask for the right patient and connect appropriately.

Right Flow- To ensure the right flow rate is used.

Good Fit- To ensure a good mask seal or fit.

Good Airway -To ensure an open airway and effective breathing.

Positioning-To ensure the correct positioning of the injured person.

Documentation and Good House Keeping –To maintain the oxygen check lists, documentation in the event of an incident.

Good House Keeping -To maintain, cleaning, restocking, refilling cylinder and correct storage.

sections.title: Location of Oxygen at the Dive Site

sections.content:
Good Practice Point- The Dive Team must be able to react in an emergency and should be familiar with the first aid equipment provided at the dive site and the required response to a medical emergency.

The response time for provision of First-Aid or Basic Life Support (BLS) should be less than 4 minutes this includes the use of oxygen and an Automated External Defibrillator (AED).

Any form of Decompression Illness (DCI) must be treated immediately.

2.1. Glossary
sections.title: Summary
Big medical words and abbreviations
sections.content:
In no particular order. There is no  need to study big words for exams but these are nice to know!

Standards of Care:Everyone has the belief (expectation) that people called to help with an emergency are able to give care with an acceptable (adequate) level of knowledge and skill.  This is referred to as the ‘Standards of Care’.  This systematic standard approach helps to maintain and improve the quality of care.HHH ABC + Rapid Assessment:Hazards: Hello: Help: Airway: Breathing: Circulation and a rapid assessment to identify obvious injury or illness.Non Rebreather Mask:An oxygen delivery device (face mask) that can be used to continuously administer oxygen to an Injured Person (Alive Diver).Demand Valve Inhalator:An oxygen delivery device (face mask) that can be used to administer oxygen on demand to an Injured Person (Alive Diver).Regurgitation:Passive expulsion of stomach contents (Dead diver - this is dangerous as the Injured Person (IP) can not protect their own airway and may breathe in their own vomit!).Vomiting:Forceful expulsion of stomach contents (Alive Diver - this generally is OK as it means the Injured Person can protect their own airway!).Hypoxia:Lack of (hypo) Oxygen (oxia).Diffusion:Movement of gases.Perfusion:Movement of blood / blood circulation.Ventilation:Process of breathing in and out.

Occasional Gasps or Agonal Respiration:Abnormal breathing pattern caused by the body's attempt to breathe after the heart has stopped.

It is important to note that that gasping can be mistaken as normal breathing. They key difference is that the gasps are irregular when compared to normal regular breathing. Therefore, always start CPR in an unresponsive person who is gasping.

Basic life support:BLS:The foundation of saving lives after the heart has stopped beating.CPR:Cardiopulmonary ResuscitationAutomated External Defibrillator:AEDAirway Adjunct:Devices to assist keeping the airway open.Barrier Device:A face mask designed to protect the First-Aider from having any contact with the Injured Persons (IP) body fluids!Pocket Mask Resuscitator:A barrier device that can be used to administer breaths to an Injured Person with no life signs (Dead Diver).Bag Valve Mask (BVM) Resuscitator:A barrier device that can be used to deliver breaths to an Injured Person with no life signs (Dead Diver).

2.2. Review of Physiology

Oxygen is vital to life.

No living cell can survive long without oxygen.

The brain and heart will begin to die if they receive to little oxygen supply (Hypoxia). They will die and never be replaced after 4-10 minutes.

Good Practice Point- Oxygen is provided to prevent hypoxia (lack of oxygen).

3. Portable Oxygen Systems
sections.title: Basic Physics and Physiology

subsections.title: Physics
subsections.content:
Oxygen reaches the body according to Daltons law and Henrys law.

Very basically, as the oxygen percentage is increased so is the partial pressure of the gasses that are breathed (Daltons Law). The breathed gasses become soluble, and dissolves with in your body (Henrys Law).

Physiology

Gas exchange in the body is a process of adequate:

Ventilation- Breathing

Diffusion– Gas exchange

Perfusion– Blood Flow

subsections.title: How Does Oxygen get into the body
subsections.content:
Ventilationis the movement of a volume of gas into and out of the lungs.

Air must be drawn through the nose and mouth, down the airways, all the way to the tiny little air sacs known as alveoli. These little air sacs (alveoli) are surrounded by tiny blood vessels known as capillaries. The alveoli and tiny blood vessels are only one cell thick  - about 1/20th the thickness of a piece of paper!

Good Practice Point.Gas exchange can only take place in the alveoli.

Respirationis the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide.

Oxygen and carbon dioxide passes into the blood and is transported throughout the body by the process of diffusion.

Good Practice Point -The normal breathing rate for an adult is 10 - 20 breaths per minute

How is Oxygen Transported to the Body

Oxygen (O2) is not a very soluble gas and therefore needs help to get to the body tissues. It is carried to the body via the Red Blood Cells (RBC).

Haemoglobin (HB) is a protein found in the red blood blood cell and is designed to carry oxygen so it can be transported throughout the body.

Red Blood Cells (RBC) get their red colour from the combination of haemoglobin (Hb) and oxygen (O2)

97% of oxygen (O2) is carried by the haemoglobin (Hb)

3% is dissolved in the plasma of the blood.

Portable oxygen administration systems must be at the site of a diving operation.  The oxygen administration system must be:

Easily accessible

Clearly labeled

Sufficient supply to last until the next point of access

All components must be rated oxygen clean to prevent any risk of fire or explosion.

High Pressure (HP) oxygen Cylinder with pillar valve (on/off valve)

Pressure Regulator

Connecting tubing or hose

Oxygen Delivery Device (Mask)

Care should be taken in the handling and use of medical oxygen cylinders.
sections.title: Portable Oxygen Administration Systems

sections.content:
All cylinders should be in-date. Make sure you can locate the visual test date (usually a sticker) and the hydrostatic test date (Usually stamped into the cylinder neck).

Visual required every two (2) years

Hydro required every four (4) years
sections.title: High Pressure Oxygen Cylinders

subsections.title: Identification
subsections.content:
All cylinders containing compressed medical oxygen shall be colour coded in accordance with local regulation.  In South Africa it is controlled by SANS 1006 and the cylinder shall have a black body and white shoulder. In other countriess it may be colour coded all white or Green.

In every country there is a series of regulations and standards for the manufacturing and use of oxygen cylinders.  This is a general overview.  Please ensure you are familiar with the systems you are using to ensure safety.

subsections.title: Small Portable Cylinders (Pin Index)
subsections.content:
The cylinders are usually small and easy to carry.

3L aluminum pin index cylinders or approximately 0.49kg, containing approximately 420L of oxygen (D)

10L aluminum pin index cylinders or approximately 1.84 kg, containing approximately 1400L of oxygen (F)

The filling pressure for smaller portable oxygen cylinders is usually 140  - 150 bar (±2,200psi)

sections.title: Pillar Valves (on/off valves)
sections.content:
This valve is the most fragile component and allows the cylinder to be turned on and off.

The most common type of valve used is thePin Indexand is usually opened using a "key".

Safety First.The unique configuration of holes and pins match precisely to eliminate connection of the wrong cylinder to the wrong pressure regulator.

Always open valves slowly.Rapidly opening valves can cause flash fires.

sections.title: Pressure Regulator
sections.content:
The pressure regulator controls the flow rate of oxygen delivery.

Always ensure the pressure regulator is designed for use with cylinder pressures up to 3,000 psi/200 bar.

It is important that the oxygen regulator be free from oil or grease, otherwise a violent explosion may occur.
